item.title: Example Page 1
item.description:

item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: Impact of epidemiologic models on government policy and response to the COVID-19 pandemic in the Philippines
Use of text analysis and topic modelling in policy analysis
CoMo modelling tool for the Philippines
comoparams: R utility tool to extract, process and structure Philippines-specific datasets for use in the CoMo Consortium Model
The COVID-19 International Modelling Consortium (CoMo Consortium)
The utility and impact of epidemiological models in the development of policy and formulation of interventions during an epidemic
COVID-19 Situation in the Philippines
item.description:
Evolution of the pandemic in the Philippines

On 11th of January 2020, the Philippines Department of Health issued its first advisory concerning persons who had travel history to Wuhan, China which at that time was the epicentre of the COVID-19 outbreak. The issuance of this advisory was triggered by the first death attributable to COVID-19 in China. On the 21st of January, the first patient-under-investigation (PUI) who happened to be a traveler from China was investigated and was pronounced as negative of COVID-19. One week after (Jan. 28), the DOH convened the Inter-agency Task Force on Emerging and Re-emerging Infections (IATF-EID). The nCOV-tracker (https://ncovtracker.doh.gov.ph/), which is a public dashboard that shows the number of PUM, PUI, and confirmed cases, was also launched on the same day. The DOH convened the first command conference on the next day with regional directors as participants. On Jan. 30, the first confirmed case of COVID-19, which was an imported case from Wuhan, China, was declared. This happened during the same day when the World Health Organization (WHO) had declared COVID-19 as a Public Health Emergency of International Concern. The next day, a travel ban to and from Hubei, China was promulgated by the Philippine government.

On the 1st of Feb., the first mortality due to COVID-19, who was a close contact of the first imported case, was pronounced in the Philippines. On Feb 5, a 60-year-old female Chinese PUI tested positive and was declared as the 3rd case in the Philippines. This prompted the Epidemiology Bureau of the DOH, along with the Philippine National Police- Criminal Investigation and Detection Group (PNP-CIDG), to start tracing the contacts of the confirmed cases.

A month after (March 5), two more cases were confirmed in the country and were added in the roster. Having no travel history as confirmed by the Bureau of Immmigration, the 5th case was pronounced to be the first local case on March 7. This prompted the DOH to raise the COVID-19 ALERT System to Code Red sublevel 1. Mr. Rodrigo Duterte, the current president, made a nationwide declaration of a State of Public Health Emergency due to COVID-19. A day prior COVID-19 was declared as a pandemic by the WHO Director-General on March 11, the president issued a region-wide suspension of all classes in Metro Manila. On March 12, the IATF-EID and the DOH raised the COVID Alert System to Code Red sublevel 2 placing Metro Manila under General Community Quarantine as a means of curbing viral transmission. On March 16, the president declared a nationwide declaration of a State of Calamity and placed the entire Luzon Island on an Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) until April 14. On April 6, Mr. Duterte pronounced in a night press conference that he is inclining towards ECQ extension until April 30.

Current COVID-19 epidemic models in the Philippines

Presented below are some of the current models that are focused on Metro Manila (National Capital Region).

Model/Proponents Status quo estimated peak size (include detected and undetected) Status quo peak time Remarks
SEIR Model/UPD ModApp 250000 - 550000 as of 1 April 2020 April 2020 S0 = 1 million; R0 = 1.48; cumulative number of infected = 900000
SIR provincial/city-level/UPLB Biomathematics Team 140000 - 320000 as of 4 April 2020 April - June 2020 R0 = 1.5 - 4 (R0 most likely at 1.5 - 2.5); Peak size is 25% of total infected
SIR Model/Darwin Bandoy 250000 End of June S0 = 1 million; R0 = 2.5 (95% CI 1.1 = 2.5)

A web-based disease surveillance platform that uses deterministic compartmental modeling was developed by people from Ateneo Center for Computing Competency and Research (ACCCRe) of Ateneo de Manila University, University of the Philippines Manila - National Telehealth Center (UP-NTHC), and the Department of Health-Epidemiology Bureau developed. This was known as FASSSTER, or Feasibility Analysis of Syndromic Surveillance using Spatio-Temporal Epidemiological Modeler or FASSSTER. In modeling projections, this platform uses the following interventions: community quarantine, social distancing, and optimal testing on the total number of confirmed cases, deaths, and recoveries over time. Data generated from this platform are being used by the Inter-agency Task Force (IATF) in their recommendations and the governmentâs decision to extend the enhanced community quarantine (ECQ) until April 30. Presented below are the scenarios that have been modelled.

Scenario Peak number of cases Peak dates
Do nothing 2000000 May 30
ECQ implemented but lifted on 14 April with health system capacity at 25% 1500000 July 31
ECQ implemented but lifted on 14 April with health system capacity at 50% 15000 May 4
ECQ implemented but lifted on 30 April with health system capacity at 75% 6800 May 21

In this modelling, peak date refers to the day with the highest number of cases. The projected maximum number of active confirmed positive cases for the duration of the outbreak is referred to as the âPeak of active confirmed casesâ. Meanwhile, health system capacity was defined as a function of (1) testing capacity and (2) health management capacity. Testing capacity refers to the availability of test kits, testing centers with quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) machines, trained health workers to perform testing, and turnaround time of test results. On the other hand, health management capacity refers to the availability of health facilities, medical devices and health workers to manage the confirmed positive cases so that they are isolated and given proper medical care.

item.title: COVID-19 International Modelling Consortium (CoMo) in the Philippines
item.description:
The application of the CoMo Consortium model to the Philippines context is the main project of the CoMo Philippines team and is the reason for the formation of the team. The CoMo Consortium model is described here in more detail.

The CoMo Philippines team seeks to answer the following:

  1. How can the CoMo Consortium model inform preparations for a post-lockdown scenario?

  2. What combination of interventions could work best in the Philippines?

The national team will compare the CoMo Consortium model against other, locally developed models. This will support the development of a local model that better reflects the dynamic local situation and appropriate responses to the COVID-19 epidemic in the Philippines. Other models being used are the official FASSTER COVID-19 module and the UP COVID-19 Pandemic Response Team model.

item.title: An example preprint / working paper
item.description:
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic

Academic | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation

item.title: An example journal article

Click the Cite button above to demo the feature to enable visitors to import publication metadata into their reference management software.
